audio_caption: The clip opens with a male speaker introducing a module on AI first engineering, focusing on AI in banking and the use of deep learning. He mentions the division into modules. He proceeds to describe the first module, discussing what's happening to legacy banks and observes they may not be doing as well as they used to, but they are acquiring newer banks as a plan for the future. The clip ends with the speaker saying, "I."

The clip begins with a male speaker, in a somewhat hurried and lecturing tone, providing a "little summary of the types of AI that one might see in banking." He lists different types, including "natural language processing, chat bots," and "image analysis." He then mentions robotic process automation and discusses the distinction between predictive analysis and machine learning. He goes on to discuss how these analysis types are used to "mine out nuggets" from large data sets for various purposes like stock investment and detecting potential defaults. The speaker ends by saying more details will follow, thanking the audience. The clip concludes with a sound reminiscent of a musical interlude, possibly an orchestral piece.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker presenting news quotes from January 30th of the current year, mentioning Lloyds announcing closings and the closure of 3300 branches in the UK over the past four years, as well as the decline in ATMs due to reduced cash usage. The speaker notes that the remaining ATMs are becoming more expensive, because they "no longer have enough free things". The speaker concludes by saying "this is hardly surprising". The overall tone of the speaker is informative and somewhat neutral.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the shift from physical to digital banking, noting that fewer trips to the bank are needed nowadays, except perhaps for loans, currency exchange, and depositing checks. He then mentions the prevalence of electronic transfers, concluding that there are fewer reasons for physical banks, although some remain.

The clip starts with a male speaker relaying a story from December of the previous year about a large Italian bank that is cutting jobs and branches, requiring them to transition to digital services and train their staff. His tone is informative. Next, he transitions to discussing statistics regarding Bank of America's branches over the last ten years, observing that they are not declining dramatically but are down by about 20%. The speaker sounds almost monotone in the second part.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing "a little art" in the United Kingdom, mentioning the Royal Bank of Scotland closing 74% and Lloyds closing 31%, he added, "we had a story about them earlier." He concluded that it seemed to be "rather more closing in the United Kingdom." Then, someone says, "Hello."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the story of Citibank, mentioning a decline in contact with people at the bank by 6%, a 7% increase in the use of electronic statements, and a larger online banking growth for both mobile and desktop customers. He states that the information is from January of this year.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing AI and its impact on the banking industry, stating that AI will cut the bank size of bank staff. He notes that AI is used pretty generally and that some AI is just straightforward IT. The speaker continues to describe the computer's ability to do things that people otherwise do.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing job cuts, specifically mentioning Deutsche Bank and the digitalization of industries. His tone is conversational and informative. He specifies this is not just AI but manual work.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Goldman Sachs, noting its good reputation as a business bank and its underperformance. He attributes this to a poor strategy regarding AI and digitization. He contrasts its performance with that of standard US banks and mentions that European banks have fared even worse, citing Deutsche Bank's loss despite being a large European bank. The audio ends with a brief, ambiguous sound.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a related story about job losses. He attempts to quantify the losses over the next ten years, mentioning that "standard banks are meant to reduce their head count by 9 percent" which unfortunately translates to "a third of a million people." His tone is informative and slightly somber.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing fintech companies, describing them as digital, AI-oriented startups and stating that they have grown by 90%. He then notes that fintech companies only represent 5% of the legacy banks, resulting in a smaller increase in jobs compared to the losses. The speaker sounds informative and analytical.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a thoughtful tone, who describes a financial strategy involving banks and fintech companies. He notes that the banks finance the fintechs, observe their performance, and then "buy them up" to create a "fintech enabled" bank.

Okay.

The audio clip starts with a man speaking, who indicates that there are real numbers for 2022. He points out there's an increase predicted for incumbents, with an even bigger increase for FinTech. The FinTech increase grows up to 2025, 2030, but this increase may not happen with the new virus. The man says it turns into a decrease by 2030. He is talking to the listener and summarizes that technology and AI, big data, will lead to an enhanced number of a certain type of job and a decrease in another type of job. He concludes the message and thanks the listener.
